items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Changes proposed to the district's credit by examination policy were presented for review and first reading at the July 1, 2013, meeting. The changes, which have been approved by the Academic and Professional Matters Committee, De Anza College Academic Senate, Foothill College Academic Senate, and the Chancellor's Advisory Council, bring the policy into alignment with current practices and regulations. Strikethrough on the attachment represents text to be deleted, and new language is indicated by bold, underlined text.
	 
A new administrative procedure developed and approved in conjunction with the policy revision is included for purposes of clarification. 
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor, extension 6104
Additional contact names:
Carolyn Holcroft, extension 7429
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Linda Thor recommends that the Board of Trustees adopt revised board policy 6030 Credit by Examination.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Revised board policy 2305 concerning the annual organizational meeting of the Board of Trustees was presented for review and first reading at the July 1, 2013, meeting.  The revision clarifies the time frame for the annual organizational meeting in election years and changes the policy number to coincide with the system used by the Community College League of California's (CCLC) Policy and Procedure Service. Strikethrough on the attachment represents text to be deleted, and new language is indicated by bold, underlined text.
	 
The Chancellor's Advisory Council approved the revised board policy electronically by consensus on June 14, 2013.  
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor, extension 6104

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District owns surplus furniture that has been replaced with new (see attached lists, 3 pages).  It has been determined that the furniture is in such poor condition that it is unusable.  District staff estimates the value of this furniture to be less than $100.00 in the aggregate.
	 
California Education Code 81452(c) provides that if the governing board, by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property, is of insufficient value to defray the costs of arranging a sale, the property may be disposed of in the local public dump on order of any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board.
	 
District Staff will dismantle the items and recycle or dispose of the components appropriately.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Interim Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Make a finding that the items are of insufficient value to defray the costs of arranging a sale and authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services to recycle the items or dispose of them in the local public dump.
items.item_text: Recycle and Dispose of District Property
items.item_text_raw: 6. Recycle and Dispose of District Property

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The District has 5 pallets of computers, monitors, printers, and miscellaneous electronic equipment (See attached Surplus Forms, 9 pages).  The District’s Educational Technology Services Department (ETS) staff has determined that the items are obsolete and of no further use to the District.  In accordance with the Electronic Waste Recycling Act these items are considered electronic waste. The estimated aggregate market value of this electronic equipment is less than $5,000.00.
	 
California Education Code 81452(a) provides that if the governing board by a unanimous vote of those members present, finds that the property, whether one or more items, does not exceed in value the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), the property may be sold by any employee of the District empowered for that purpose by the board. 
	 
Purchasing Services will post a notice on Bid Net and call for competitive bids from authorized State of California material handlers, collectors, and recyclers.  Proceeds will be deposited to the District’s general fund. 
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Interim Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services
Is backup provided?
items.item_recommendation: Make a finding that the property does not exceed $5,000.00 in value and authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services to sell the items in accordance with Education Code 81452(a).
items.item_text: Sale of Miscellaneous Surplus Electronic Equipment
items.item_text_raw: 7. Sale of Miscellaneous Surplus Electronic Equipment

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Engineering and design services are required for a variety of small maintenance, alteration, repair and upgrade projects, typically less than $350,000 in construction cost.  Projects will generally be constructed through a public bid process and may require submission to the Division of the State Architect (DSA) for review and closeout.  Funding will be provided from Plant Services Capital Outlay Projects Fund.
	 
Services will include mechanical, electrical, and civil engineering studies, the preparation of plans and specifications suitable for public bidding, bidding support, construction administration, startup and testing, acceptance, and closeout services.  Initial services may also include planning and programming, recording of existing conditions, coordination of relocations, cost estimating and other miscellaneous services.  Fees may be negotiated on an ongoing hourly basis or as a lump sum fee for a project.
  
The District issued Request for Qualifications (RFQ) #1648 for Engineering Services for Maintenance & Operations Repairs/Upgrade projects. The intent of the RFQ was to establish a pool of firms qualified to provide services for a variety of projects to be undertaken by the District.  The RFQ was advertised on Bidnet, and local firms thought to be qualified were contacted directly and encouraged to apply.  On June 28, 2013, the District received responses to the RFQ from:
	 
CSW / ST2;  Salas Obrien;  Gayner;  Sandis;  Ati;  Interface;  Gordon Prill / BKF;  KPFF.
	 
A selection committee, comprised of District personnel, deliberated regarding the completeness and quality of responses, experience related to District projects, qualifications and experience of proposed team members, ability to dedicate the appropriate quantity and quality of staff, and fee structure. All of the respondent firms were deemed to meet the qualifications needed to be included in the pool.
	 
The listed firms will be considered and assigned to projects according to project needs, experience and qualifications specific to the project, ability to meet the schedule, and cost effectiveness during the next three years.  Firms listed as qualified by the District may be selected to provide services for multiple projects or for no projects.
	 
No commitment was made in the RFQ to employ every selected firm. Selections to provide services for individual projects will be based upon project needs, experience and qualification related to the project, availability relative to project schedules, references, and cost proposals.  
	 
Submitted by:
Charles Allen x6150
Additional contact names:
Lester Lyons x5437, Steve Schmidt x 6168
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Executive Director of Facilities, Operations, and Construction Management Charles Allen recommends that the Board approve the list of firms to be included as a pool of prequalified firms to provide Engineering Services for small Maintenance & Operations Repairs/Upgrade projects for a period of three years.

items.item_text_raw: 8. Engineering and design consulting services for small maintenance, alteration, repair and upgrade projects

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill has been awarded $300,000 in funding from the California Community Chancellor's Office Division of Workforce and Economic Development for a one-year (July 9, 2013-June 30, 2014) grant for a Deputy Sector Navigator to work with the Energy Efficiency industry and Utilities sector in the Bay Area.  This grant is in support of the Doing What Matters for Jobs and the Economy framework to enhance collaborative regional work on curricular pathways in sectors important to regional economies.  The grant project is one of a number of Bay Area projects that will support the creation of a network of Deputy Sector Navigators. This project builds on FHDA earlier work, including the SolarTech Workforce Innovations Collaborative (SWIC) project in the Energy Sector.
	 
Catherine Ayers was named the Deputy Sector Navigator on this award as detailed in the attached Independent Contract Agreement dated July 9, 2013 because of her experience with the energy efficiency industry and her knowledge of workforce development in the community colleges.  As required by the Chancellor's Office, the Deputy Sector Navigator is an 80% to full-time role, working with colleges, industry and other stakeholders for this sector in the Bay Area.
	 
The Independent Contractor Agreement was authorized by John Mummert, Vice President of Workforce Development and Institutional Advancement, for $129,200 for contracted services, $4,210 for expenses, for a total contract amount of $133,410.
	 
Submitted by:
  Judy Miner
Additional contact names:
  John Mummert, x 7070  Skip Barnes, x 7794
Is backup provided?
items.item_recommendation: Foothill administration recommends approval of this agreement
items.item_text: Independent Contractor Agreement with Catherine Ayers
items.item_text_raw: 14. Independent Contractor Agreement with Catherine Ayers

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis: 
	 
The purpose of a Valley Transportation Authority (VTA) EcoPass agreement is to provide annual transit passes to all eligible students of Foothill-De Anza Community College District. 
	 
At the De Anza College Student Body election on May 15, 2011, a majority of students agreed that the Foothill De Anza Community College District Board of Trustees should take action to charge a mandatory quarterly fee of up to five dollars to all full-time De Anza College students and a mandatory quarterly prorated fee to all De Anza College part-time students to make VTA EcoPasses available to all De Anza students. On June 20, 2011, the Board of Trustees passed a resolution implementing the mandatory transportation fee effective fall quarter 2011 at De Anza College.
	 
At the Foothill Student Body election January 28-31, 2013, a majority of students (1112 out of 1333 students voting) agreed that the Foothill-De Anza Community College District Board of Trustees should take action to charge a mandatory quarterly fee of up to five dollars to all full-time Foothill College students and a mandatory prorated fee to all Foothill College part-time students to make a VTA EcoPass available to all students.  On March 11, 2013, the Board of Trustees passed a resolution implementing the mandatory fee. Foothill will implement the EcoPass program in winter 2014, pending resolution of discretionary exclusions.
	 
Board approval is requested for the 2013-2014 VTA EcoPass contract (September 23, 2013 - September 22, 2014).
	 
Submitted by:
Brian Murphy, President De Anza College, ext 8705 &  Judy Miner, President, Foothill College x7200
Additional contact names:
Letha Jeanpierre, VP, Finance & Educational Resources ext. 8976 & Bernata Slater VP, Institutional Resources ext 7364
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: De Anza College President Brian Murphy and Foothill College President Judy Miner recommend approval of the VTA EcoPass contract to provide annual transit passes to Foothill-De Anza Community College District students for an estimated $351,000 for the academic year 2013-2014.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The Board is requested to approve the Agreement between Foothill-De Anza Community College District and the Faculty Association, July 1, 2013 through June 30, 2016.
	 
This Agreement is dedicated to Anne Paye, former FA Chief Negotiator and long-time faculty member of the Foothill-De Anza Community College District. Anne was a tireless advocate for faculty of the District and a valued member of the joint labor-management negotiations team. Anne added insight, perseverance, problem-solving perspective, wit, humor, wisdom, and a passion for the importance and meaning of words to the process of resolving issues of mutual interest to the District and the Faculty Association and reducing those agreements to writing. A dedication is included in this Agreement, as follows:
	 
This Agreement is dedicated to
	 
Anne Paye
FA Chief Negotiator
1997-2013
	 
In grateful appreciation for her
Clear and brilliant reasoning
Unmatched ability to craft language
Gracious humor and intelligence
and
Ceaseless devotion to faculty
	 
A summary of the substantive changes, as well as a complete copy of the draft Agreement, showing proposed changes, is attached.    
	 
Submitted by:
Dorene Novotny, Vice Chancellor of Human Resources & Equal Opportunity x6211
Additional contact names:
n/a
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Dorene Novotny, Vice Chancellor of Human Resources and Equal Opportunity, recommends approval.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
It has been determined that it is in the best interest of the District to refinance its outstanding Refunding Certificates of Participation (Series 2003) (the “2003 Certificates”) through the preparation, sale and delivery of a Lease/Purchase Agreement.
	 
We are asking the Board to approve the resolution permitting the sale of a Lease/Purchase Agreement.
	 
The District would cause the execution and delivery of a Lease/Purchase Agreement (the “Lease”) to Capital One Public Funding, LLC, as the Purchaser of the Lease (the “Purchaser”).  The maximum amount authorized to be borrowed would be $8,500,000.  The Lease will carry a fixed interest rate of 1.75% for a term of eight years and save the District approximately $85,000 annually in interest expense as compared to the current terms.
	 
The Resolution would approve the form of the Lease/Purchase Agreement, Site Lease and Escrow Agreement and authorize the President of the Board, the Chancellor, the Vice Chancellor, Business Services, and the Controller to take any and all actions necessary to consummate the sale, execution and delivery of the Lease.
	 
Submitted by:
Kevin McElroy, x6201
Additional contact names:
Hector Quinonez, x6250
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services recommends approval of Resolution #2013-27 authorizing the refinancing of the 2003 Refunding Certificates of Participation and the execution and delivery of documents relating to the sale and delivery of a lease/purchase agreement and authorizing and directing certain actions in connection therewith.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Title:  Prime Contract Change Order #1
Vendor:  Guerra Construction
Agreement Date:  May 13, 2013
Campus:  De Anza College
Project Number:  274-B
Project Name:  Combined Site Improvements Phase II
Amount:  $87,363
For: 
	 
Prime Contract Change Order #01 added scope including curbs, asphalt sidewalk, handrails, irrigation and landscaping.  Added asphalt in area not previously known, provided curbs to better maintain landscape areas and to address drainage and safety, revised the handrail design to minimize potential impacts from skateboards, and added a small area of landscape replacement at Mary entry. Added scope will provide for better project longevity and campus safety.
	 
Total Change Order spending to date, including this change, is 5.86% of the original contract amount.  Funding for this change is included in the current budget.
	 
Submitted by:
Charles Allen, Executive Director, Facilities, Operations, and Construction Management,  extension 6150
Additional contact names:
Tom Armstrong, Director, Bond Program Management, De Anza College
Donna Jones-Dulin, Associate Vice President, Finance & Educational Resources, De Anza College

Vendor:  Sandis 
Agreement Date:  December 15, 2008
Campus:  De Anza College
Project Number:  274B
Project Name:  Combined Site Improvements Phase II
Amount:  $15,450
For: 
	 
Change Order #01 to the Project Authorization Amendment #D03 for the following scope:
PE-4 Vehicular Path $4,650 – Revise pathway to resolve drainage issues, add curb & gutter.

For:
	 
Construction changes due to architect/engineer-directed drawing revisions, College direction, and field conditions discovered during the course of construction.  Field condition changes include a number of repairs to existing building framing and, most notably, removal of asbestos-containing materials in two buildings which was not discovered during design.    Other issues include correcting the fire alarm wiring specification to match other campus buildings, and added demolition work not shown on the drawings.  
	 
The unanticipated asbestos removal and floor design changes requested by the College result in no-cost time extensions to project milestone dates, but the final project completion date is not changed as a result.
	 
This change plus all previously approved change orders are equal to 1.96% of the base contract value.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On December 7, 2009 and January 19, 2010, Charles Allen, Executive Director of Facilities, Operations and Construction Management, provided information briefings to the Board regarding the use of the Lease-Leaseback project delivery method, including the contractor selection process, for District projects.  The briefings included a discussion of the legal aspects of the process as well as its risks and benefits.  
	 
On February 4, 2013, the Board authorized the use of the Lease-Leaseback contractor selection process for the De Anza College Measure C Project 239 – Flint Parking Structure Repairs in accordance with Education Code 81335. 
	 
Purchasing Services staff legally advertised the Lease-Leaseback Request for Qualifications and Request for Proposals (RFQ/RFP) #1426-239 for the Flint Parking Structure Repairs on March 6, March 13, April 3, and April 10, 2013 in the San Jose Post Record.  Furthermore, nine (9) Builders Exchanges and Plan Rooms were notified of the RFQ/RFP and a copy of the legal advertisement was also posted online at “BidNet” at www.govbids.com. Purchasing Services staff also contacted twenty-four (24) companies regarding the RFQ/RFP opportunity. 
	 
Representatives from eight (8) contractor companies attended at least one of the two mandatory pre-submittal conferences held on March 19 and April 17, 2013. Two (2) contractors, C. Overaa & Company (Overaa) and Taber Construction Company (Taber), submitted Statements of Qualifications (SOQ’s) in response to RFQ/RFP #1426-239 by the May 8, 2013 deadline. 
	 
A Selection Committee was established to evaluate the responses to the RFQ/RFP. The eight (8) member Selection Committee consisted of: Donna Jones-Dulin – Associate Vice President of College Operations; Lester Lyons – Associate Director of Facilities; Tom Armstrong – Director of Bond Program Management – De Anza College; Roseanne Sciacchitano – District Project Manager; Ella Bisconti – Project Manager for Gilbane-MAAS; Merideth Marschack – Noll & Tam Architects; Jonathan Stafford – Simpson Gumpertz & Heger; and Annette Perez – Purchasing Services Senior Buyer.  The committee evaluated each of the SOQ’s for responsiveness (including financial capacity, safety record, and similar project experiences) and invited Overaa and Taber to continue with the interview and RFP steps.
	 
The Selection Committee conducted interviews with Overaa and Taber on June 12, 2013 and responses to the RFP were received on June 26, 2013.  The RFP responses included competitive fee proposals for preconstruction services, construction services, contractor’s contingency, and contractor’s overhead and profit.  Based on the proposals provided in relation to the scores of the RFQ and the interviews, Overaa had the score with the lowest cost per qualification point and earned the top ranking. 
	 
The Selection Committee recommends award of a Preconstruction Services Agreement (see attached) to Overaa so that it can develop a Preliminary Construction Schedule, proceed with reviewing the design documentation for constructability, prequalify subcontractors for bidding, obtain competitive bids from subcontractors, and develop a Guaranteed Maximum Price (GMP) for the project. Overaa’s fee for Preconstruction Services is $40,112. The Preconstruction Services Agreement, paragraph VII(C), provides that the contractor will be reimbursed at actual cost for reimbursable services defined as printing, advertising, and site condition confirmation. Overaa proposed and District staff agreed that Overaa’s estimated reimbursable services will not exceed  $25,000.  The total not to exceed cost for the Preconstruction Services Agreement is $65,112.
	 
Provided that District and Overaa agree to a GMP, project milestone dates, and completion dates indicated in the Preliminary Construction Schedule, District staff plans to return to the Board as early as December 2, 2013 and recommend award of the Site Lease and Facilities Lease agreements to Overaa to construct the Project based upon DSA-approved construction documents within the agreed-upon duration for an amount not to exceed the GMP.  Under the two agreements, the District will lease District-owned land to Overaa and in return Overaa will agree to construct the project pursuant to the District’s Construction Provisions and Overaa’s responses to RFQ/RFP #1426-239.  The District will receive incremental title to the constructed property in accordance with payments made.  The District will pay for and take title to all improvements no later than completion of construction of the project at which time the leases will be terminated.
	 
These services are within the project budget and are funded by Measure C.
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Interim Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Tom Armstrong, Director of Bond Program Management – De Anza College; Charles Allen, Executive Director of Facilities, Operations, and Construction Management; Annette Perez, Senior Buyer, Purchasing Services. 
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: Approve C. Overaa & Company as the Lease-Leaseback contractor for the Flint Parking Structure Repairs project at De Anza College and authorize Gina Bailey, Interim Director of Purchasing Services, to award the attached Preconstruction Services Agreement for the project to C. Overaa & Company.
items.item_text: Award Lease-Leaseback Preconstruction Services Agreement for Flint Parking Structure Repairs at De Anza College - $65,112 (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 23. Award Lease-Leaseback Preconstruction Services Agreement for Flint Parking Structure Repairs at De Anza College - $65,112 (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
This revision is required to implement Bond list changes that are needed to adjust and prioritize approved project scopes and funding at Foothill and De-Anza College.  
	 
De-Anza Budget Transfer #38 includes the following actions:
Transfer $548,638.57 from Project 299, De Anza Program Contingency and $18,590.11 (Series A), $4,109.38 (Series B) and $283,589.39 (Series C) of Interest Earned in Quarter 2 & Quarter 3 Fiscal Year 2012/2013 to Project 216, Library to augment the project budget.
Transfer $35,000 in savings from Project 247, G-Building into Project 218, Signage and Wayfinding to augment the budget for kiosk signage.
Transfer $22,000 from Project 299, De Anza Program Contingency into Project 274, Combined Site Improvements to augment the project budget.
Note that current budget for Project 216 will have an additional funding source of $145,072.55 due to PG&E Rebates not shown here.
Foothill Budget Transfer #40 includes the following actions:
Transfer $22,699.50 (Series B) and $283,589.39 (Series C) of interest earned in Quarter 2 and Quarter 3 Fiscal Year 2012/2013 to Project 199, Foothill Program Contingency.
Submitted by:
Charles Allen

Art Heinrich, Bernata Slater, Tom Armstrong and Donna Jones-Dulin

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The scope of work requires the contractor to demolish and dispose the existing scoreboard, timers, supporting equipment, and surface mounted conduit and wires at the De Anza College Pool facility.  The scoreboard is past its useful life and does not function properly.  The scope of work also requires the contractor to transport and install one (1) owner-furnished outdoor video display scoreboard and two (2) pace/shot clocks, including accessories. The contractor will also provide and install the associated wiring, conduit, fiber optic cable, steel supporting structure, anchors and supports for the scoreboard and the pace/shot clocks.  The manufacturer will program the scoreboard during the final phase of the project.
	 
The Architect, Arch-Pac, Inc. prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department.
	 
Bid Document #1636R-200F was legally advertised on June 19, June 26, and July 1, 2013 in the San Jose Post Record.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges and was posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Two (2) general contractors attended the non-mandatory Bid Walk that was held on July 3, 2013 and Measure C bond team members continued outreach efforts to generate interest in the project with potential contractors.  Bids were publicly opened and read on July 17, 2013 at 3:00 p.m. by Purchasing Services.  The bid results are shown below:
	 
GENERAL CONTRACTORS
BASE BID PROPOSAL AMOUNT
R.C. Benson & Sons, Inc. General Contractors
$59,100
Rodan Builders, Inc.
$80,675
	 
The apparent lowest responsive and responsible bidder was R.C. Benson & Sons, Inc. General Contractors (R.C. Benson).  Purchasing Services staff has confirmed that R.C. Benson successfully completed Project 153C – Psychology Offices Acoustical Improvement at Foothill College in 2011 and Project 116 – Deck Repair and Window Replacement for the Japanese Cultural Center at Foothill College in 2013. R.C. Benson is currently also under contract to construct Project 200F – PE-6 ADA Shower upgrades at De Anza College this summer.
	 
The bid price of $59,100 for the base bid proposal amount submitted by R.C. Benson exceeds the architect’s estimate of $55,000, however, it is within the overall Project #200F budget of $82,479.  Therefore, the Measure C bond team recommends award a contract for the base bid proposal amount to R.C. Benson.  This project is funded by Measure C. 
	 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Int. Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Charles Allen, Tom Armstrong, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services, Gina Bailey, to award a contract pursuant to Bid Document #1636R-200F – Scoreboard Replacement at De Anza College in the aggregate amount of $59,100 to R.C. Benson & Sons, Inc. General Contractors.
items.item_text: Award a contract pursuant to Bid Document #1636R-200F – Scoreboard Replacement at De Anza College - $59,100 (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 25. Award a contract pursuant to Bid Document #1636R-200F – Scoreboard Replacement at De Anza College - $59,100 (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
The project scope consists of paving and drainage repairs and improvements in two Foothill College campus areas:  asphalt paving repairs and drainage improvements in Lots 2 and 3; and storm water management and hillside stabilization at Lot 2A.  The two scopes of work will be funded separately; Measure C Project #144 will fund Lot 2 and 3, and Plant Services Capital Outlay Projects will fund the Lot 2A project.
					 
Sandis Civil Engineers prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department.
					 
Bid #1649-144 was legally advertised in the San Jose Post Record on June 5 and June 12, 2013.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Four (4) general contractors attended the mandatory Bid Walk that was held on June 19, 2013.  Bids were publicly opened and read on July 9, 2013 at 3:00 p.m. by Purchasing Services.  The bid results are shown below:
					 
General Contractors
Total Cost for Lot 2/3 incl. an allowance for unforeseen conditions of $5,000
Total Cost for Lot 2A
Total Base Bid Proposal Amount
ER Brothers Company, Inc. 
$69,290
$42,870
$112,160
Rodan Builders, Inc. 
$75,000
$103,000
$178,000
					 
					 
The apparent lowest responsive and responsible bidder is ER Brothers Company, Inc. (ER Brothers).  Purchasing staff confirmed that ER Brothers has successfully completed projects for other public entities such as City of San Mateo and City of Menlo Park.  Additionally, ER Brothers recently began work on Project 175, Art Room Lighting & Multimedia Upgrade at Foothill College. 
					 
The bid price of $112,160 submitted by ER Brothers exceeds the combined construction estimate of $102,000 ($65,000 for Lot 2/3 and $37,000 for Lot 2A) but is within the total budget of the combined funding sources.  The Measure C Project #144 has a total budget of $150,000 reserved for the Lot 2/3 repairs and Plant Services Capital Outlay Projects fund has a total budget of $60,000 for a combined budget of $210,000.  Therefore, the Measure C bond team and the Facilities Department recommend award of a contract for the Total Base Bid Proposal Amount to ER Brothers. 
Submitted by:
Gina Bailey, Int. Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Charles Allen, Art Heinrich, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
					No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services, Gina Bailey, to award a contract pursuant to Bid #1649-144, Minor Site Improvements at Foothill College in the amount of $112,160 to ER Brothers Company, Inc.
items.item_text: Award a contract pursuant to Bid #1649-144, Minor Site Improvements at Foothill College - $112,160 (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 26. Award a contract pursuant to Bid #1649-144, Minor Site Improvements at Foothill College - $112,160 (ACTION)

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
De Anza College standardized on Krueger International (KI) faculty office furniture and classroom furniture in 2002 with the assistance of the architecture firm HLW International LLP.  They identified campus specific furniture performance and service specifications that addressed concerns regarding flexibility, function, durability, quality, safety, comfort, and aesthetics.  
 
De Anza College currently requires several purchases of Krueger International (KI) classroom and office furniture for the Advanced Technology Center (ATC) building that will be operational starting Winter Quarter 2014. The cost of the furniture is estimated not to exceed $825,000 and it will be purchased with Measure C funds.  Because the estimated cost of the furniture will exceed the current statutory bid threshold of $83,400, the District must either conduct its own bidding and award process or obtain board authorization to utilize existing contracts awarded by other public entities pursuant to Public Contract Code (PCC) 20652. 
 
On August 2, 2010, the Board of Trustees authorized a pricing agreement and the use of two competitively bid Foundation for California Community Colleges (FCCC) contracts pursuant to PCC 20652 with Kruger International (KI). Purchasing Services negotiated with KI to obtain the highest tier discount on all of its purchases against the FCCC contracts, regardless of the dollar amount through the term of the agreement that ended July 31, 2012. This is known as a “Tier” 8 discount. The discount varies depending on the product line within a range of 52% to 61% off list price.  Although the agreement expired on July 31, 2012, the proposals obtained for the ATC building are also quoted at the “Tier” 8 pricing discount. It is highly unlikely that a separate bid process conducted by our District would result in more favorable prices, terms, and conditions than the “Tier” 8 prices offered on the FCCC contracts for the same goods and services. The FCCC contracts establish discounts for furniture inclusive of specification development services, space planning services, installation drawings, shipping and delivery costs, a 15-year non-prorated parts and labor warranty, and installation services. FCCC contract # CAC-B-008 for academic furniture is valid through October 26, 2013 and FCCC contract # CAC-B-009 for administrative furniture is valid through August 23, 2013.
 
As required by the FCCC contracts, KI makes a donation of 1% for all purchases to the California Community Colleges Scholarship Endowment.  All donations that result from the District’s purchases will be allocated to the District’s account and the resulting scholarships will go to the Foothill-De Anza students.
	 
Submitted by:
  Gina Bailey, Interim Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
  Donna Jones-Dulin, Janet Couch-Vong, Dawn Allshouse
Is backup provided?
 No
items.item_recommendation: Authorize the Interim Director of Purchasing Services to issue purchase orders to Kruger International not to exceed $825,000 to furnish the ATC with classroom and office furniture pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652 and FCCC contracts CAC-B-008 and CAC-B-009.
items.item_text: Authorize use of FCCC contracts for Advanced Technology Center furniture purchases pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652 - $825,000 (ACTION)
items.item_text_raw: 27. Authorize use of FCCC contracts for Advanced Technology Center furniture purchases pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652 - $825,000 (ACTION)
